title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ATLANTA (AP) — In a performance that will echo through the annals of NBA history, Dikembe Mutombo didn't just lead the Atlanta Hawks to victory; he authored a defensive masterpiece. The Philadelphia 76ers ran headlong into a human wall Tuesday night, falling 81-106 in a game utterly dominated by the Hawks' legendary center.

Mutombo was a force of nature, amassing a stat line so absurd it defies belief: 10 points, a staggering 27 rebounds, and 8 blocked shots. His presence in the paint was an absolute deterrent, turning every Sixers drive into a futile exercise. The 27 rebounds were a clinic in positioning and sheer will, while his eight blocks—a number that surely doesn't account for the dozens of shots he altered—sent a clear message that the lane was closed.

While Mutombo orchestrated the symphony of defense, Steve Smith provided the scoring melody, pouring in a game-high 30 points to keep the scoreboard ticking. The Hawks' balance was evident, with five players finishing in double figures, but the night belonged to one man.

For Philadelphia, there were no answers. Allen Iverson, the dynamic rookie, was held to just 18 points on 6-of-22 shooting, his forays to the basket consistently met by Mutombo's waiting hand. Derrick Coleman and Jerry Stackhouse combined for 35 points, but it was a hollow effort against the defensive tsunami.

The final score tells a story of a blowout, but the box score tells the legend of Dikembe Mutombo. On this night, he was more than a player; he was an impenetrable fortress, and the Philadelphia 76ers simply had no way to siege the gates.
